facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 239 of 1968 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 239 ,of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 17, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1130 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 17, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1130 of 1966.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court passed order on revision application of the appellant against order dated 28 January 1966 of Civil and Sessions Judge Agra.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Allahabad High Court was passed on a revision application of the appellant against the order dated 28 January, 1966 of the Civil and Sessions Judge, Agra rejecting the

facts.text: Civil and Sessions Judge Agra rejected revision against Magistrate order dated 5 June 1965 forfeiting surety bond of appellant and directing realization of Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: Civil and Sessions Judge, Agra rejecting the revision against the order of the Magistrate dated 5 June, 1965 forfeiting the surety bond of the appellant and directing the sum of Rs. 20,000 be realised from the appellant.

facts.text: Kishan Lal Gupta made application for custody of truck No. RJZ-1724 in case of State vs Sua Lal under Essential Commodities Act before Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli Kheragarh.

anchor.surface_text: The bond came to be furnished by the appellant under these circumstances. One Kishan Lal Gupta made an application for obtaining custody of truck No. RJZ-1724 in the case of State Sua Lal under the Essential Commodities Act in the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli Kheragarh.

facts.text: Truck No. RJZ-1724 was seized by police on allegation of carrying essential commodities to prohibited area.

anchor.surface_text: The truck had been seized by the police on the allegation that it was carrying, essential companymodities to a prohibited area.

facts.text: Truck was in custody of police at Fatehpur Sikri Police Station.

anchor.surface_text: The truck was in the custody of the police at Fatehpur Sikri Police Station.

facts.text: On 16 December 1963, Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli Kheragarh Agra ordered delivery of truck on furnishing two sureties of Rs. 10,000 each with personal bond of like amount.

anchor.surface_text: On 16 December, 1963 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli, Kheragarh, Agra ordered delivery of the truck be given on furnishing two sureties of, Rs. 10,000 each with the personal bond of the like amount.

facts.text: Prosecution filed revision against the order which was rejected by Additional District Magistrate Kheragarh on 1 January 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution filed a revision against the order. The Additional District Magistrate, Kheragarh rejected the revision application on 1 January, 1964 with the observation that it was for the Magistrate to decide as to who was to be given temporary custody of the truck and the matter required clarification.

facts.text: On 9 January 1964, Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli-Kheragarh ordered truck given to custody of reliable and independent person on two independent sureties of Rs. 20,000 each and personal bond of like amount.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli-Kheragarh on 9 January, 1964 ordered that the truck might be given to the custody of reliable and independent person on furnishing two independent sureties of Rs. 20,000 each and the personal bond of the like amount.

facts.text: On 13 January 1964, appellant in court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli-Kheragarh Agra declared himself surety for truck No. RJZ-1724 and gave bond to produce truck whenever ordered by court and forfeit Rs. 20,000 in default.

anchor.surface_text: It is in this companytext of events that the appellant on- 13 January, 1964 in the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli-Klieragarh, Agra declared himself surety for truck No. RJZ-1724 and gave a bond as follows - I do hereby bind myself to produce the said truck whenever ordered by the companyrt to produce the same and in case of my making default therein I bind myself to forfeit to the Government the sum of Rs. 20,000.

facts.text: On 13 January 1964, appellant gave personal bond declaring ownership of property worth Rs. 1,05,000 and would not dispose of it till bond discharged by Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: On 13 January, 1964 the appellant also gave a personal bond that he owned property worth Rs. 1,05,000 and further declared that be would number dispose of his property till the bond is discharged by the Sessions Court.

facts.text: On 1 May 1965, Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kheragarh gave notice to appellant and Kishan Lal Gupta that truck not produced and to produce it on 10 May 1965 and show cause why surety bond Rs. 20,000 not forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 May, 1965 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh gave numberice to the appellant and the other surety Kishan Lal Gupta that the truck had number been produced in the companyrt and the sureties were informed to produce the truck in the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh on 10 May, 1965 and also show cause as to why the surety bond of Rs. 20,000 should number be forfeited.

facts.text: On 5 June 1965, Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kheragarh passed order that sureties did not produce truck despite notices and failed to respond, forfeited surety bond.

anchor.surface_text: On 5 June, 1965 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh passed an order recording that in spite of numberices the sureties did number produce the truck And failed to make any response.

facts.text: Truck was not produced in court by sureties.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate further recorded in the order that under order dated 10 May, 1965 the surety bond was forfeited

facts.text: Notice given to appellant to show cause why Rs. 20,000 surety amount not realized from him, but he did not respond.

anchor.surface_text: and numberice was given to the appellant to show cause as to why the said amount of the surety was number to be realised from the appellant. In spite of service of the numberice on the appellant he did number make any response.

facts.text: On 5 June 1965, Sub-Divisional Magistrate ordered Rs. 20,000 of surety bond be realised from appellant as fine.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate under these circumstances on 5 Juno, 1965 passed an order that the amount of Rs. 20,000 of the surety bond should be realised from the appellant as a fine.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision against Magistrate's order before Civil and Sessions Judge Agra, rejected on 28 January 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application in revision against the ,order of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate. The application was before the Civil and Sessions Judge, Agra who rejected the revision application on 28 January, 1966.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision to Allahabad High Court against Sessions Judge order dated 28 January 1966, High Court dismissed on 17 May 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter went up in revision to the High Court at Allahabad against the order of the Civil and Sessions, Judge ,dated 28 January, 1966. The High Court said that there was numberexplanation as to why the truck was. number produced.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court found no explanation why truck was not produced and directed recovery of entire Rs. 20,000 bond from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found it a clear case that the entire amount of the bond be recovered from the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended before High Court that surety bond given in court of SDM Kiraoli and forfeited by SDM Kheragarh, so latter lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the point was raised that the surety bond was given in one companyrt and it was forfeited in another companyrt. The High Court did number allow the question to be raised on the ground that the point had number been raised either before the Magistrate or the Sessions Judge, and, therefore, the High Court declined to allow any such question to be raised.

facts.text: High Court refused to allow jurisdiction point as it was not raised before Magistrate or Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant companytended that the bond was exe- cuted in the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli and the order of forfeiture of the surety bond was passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh and it was only the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli which companyld forfeit the bond amount and numberother companyrt companyld.

facts.text: Surety bond given on 13 January 1964 in court of SDM Kiraoli Kheragarh Agra.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear from the records that the surety bond was given on 13 January, 1964 in the companyrt of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli Kheragarh, Agra.

facts.text: Notice dated 1 May 1965 for production of truck and forfeiture was given by court of SDM Kiraoli Kheragarh Agra signed by SDM Kheragarh.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice dated 1 May, 1965 for production of the truck and for forfeiture of the surety money in default of production was given by the companyrt of Sub-Divisional Magistrate,- Kiraoli Kheragarh, Agra and was signed by Sub- Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh.

facts.text: Order dated 5 June 1965 was by court of SDM Kiraoli-Kheragarh Agra signed by SDM Kheragarh.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated 5 June, 1965 was also by the companyrt of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli-Kheragarh, Agra and signed by Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh.

concepts.interpretation: The bond given to a court could be forfeited only by that court, but distinguished on construction of bond terms; appellant liable on default as bond was to 'the court' generally and forfeiture to Government.

concepts.interpretation: Plea of want of jurisdiction interlaced with questions of fact cannot be raised for the first time in higher court without prior raising below; High Court rightly refused.

concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdictional challenge involving facts must be raised timely

issues.text: Whether the plea that the surety bond was given in one court and it was forfeited in another court could be raised for the first time before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the point was raised that the surety bond was given in one court and it was forfeited in another court. The High Court did not allow the question to be raised on the ground that the point had not been raised either before the Magistrate or the Sessions Judge, and, therefore, the High Court declined to allow any such question to be raised. Counsel for the appellant contended that the bond was exe- cuted in the court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli and the order of forfeiture of the surety bond was passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh and it was only the court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli which could forfeit the bond amount and noother court could.

issues.text: Whether the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh had jurisdiction to forfeit the surety bond executed in the court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli-Kheragarh, on a true construction of the bond and relevant provisions

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly refused the appellant to urge this ground as to want of jurisdiction of the court of Sub- Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh to forfeit the bond amount. Such a plea of jurisdiction is interlaced with questions of fact. ... Even if the appellant were permitted to raise this question in the present case without any question of fact and purely on the construction of the bond it would appear that the appellant bound himself to produce the truck whenever ordered by the court to produce the same. Therefore, there was no undertaking to produce the truck in a particular court. The undertaking was to the court of the Magistrate. The Magistrate exercises jurisdiction in the whole district under section 12 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: The surety bond was executed in the court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli and forfeited by Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kheragarh, who lacked jurisdiction as only the former court could forfeit it

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the bond was exe- cuted in the court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli and the order of forfeiture of the surety bond was passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh and it was only the court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli which could forfeit the bond amount and noother court could.

arguments.court_reasoning: Plea interlaced with questions of fact such as possible transfer of case or redistribution of business among magistrates, and not raised before magistrate or sessions judge

arguments.claim: Provisions of section 514 CrPC and Bombay High Court decision in Ballabhdas Motiram Gupta v. Emperor require that a bond given to a court can only be forfeited by that same court

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant relied on the provisions contained in section 514 of the Criminal Procedure Code and the Bench decision of the Bombay High Court in Ballabhdas Motiram Gupta v. Emperor reported in A.I.R. 1943 Bom. 178 in support of the proposition that the bond given to a court could be forfeited only by that court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Bombay case distinguished because bond there specified particular court whereas here bond is to 'the court' generally; liability to Government on default

arguments.claim: Jurisdictional plea was rightly refused by High Court as it involves factual questions and was not raised before the magistrate or sessions judge

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly refused the appellant to urge this ground as to want of jurisdiction of the court of Sub- Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh to forfeit the bond amount. Such a plea of jurisdiction is interlaced with questions of fact. It may be that the case was transferred from the court of one Magistrate to the court of another.

arguments.claim: On true construction of the bond, the undertaking was to produce the truck whenever ordered by 'the court' meaning the magistrate's court generally which exercises jurisdiction over the whole district under section 12 CrPC, and forfeiture is to the Government

anchor.surface_text: Even if the appellant were permitted to raise this question in the present case without any question of fact and purely on the construction of the bond it would appear that the appellant bound himself to produce the truck whenever ordered by the court to produce the same. Therefore, there was no undertaking to produce the truck in a particular court.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant prayer was made for reduction of the amount. The High Court found nojustification for the same.

arguments.court_reasoning: No justification provided; no explanation as to why truck was not produced

holdings.text: The High Court rightly refused to entertain the plea of want of jurisdiction raised for the first time, as it is interlaced with questions of fact such as possible transfer of cases or redistribution of business among magistrates, and was not raised before the lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly refused the appellant to urge this ground as to want of jurisdiction of the court of Sub- Divisional Magistrate, Kheragarh to forfeit the bond amount. Such a plea of jurisdiction is interlaced with questions of fact. It may be that the case was transferred from the court of one Magistrate to the court of another. It may be that a particular court is abolished and the jurisdiction of the abolished court is transferred to the other court. It may be that allocation of business is changed or redistributed among Magistrates Court from time to time. If this particular ground had been urged at the proper time these facts could have been elucidated. It will appear from the records that the surety bond was given on 13 January, 1964 in the court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Kiraoli Kheragarh, Agra.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea involves factual inquiries (e.g., case transfer, court abolition, business redistribution) which could have been clarified if raised timely below; records show notices and orders issued by same court under different magistrate signatures.

holdings.text: On true construction of the surety bond, the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kheragarh had jurisdiction to forfeit the bond executed before Sub-Divisional Magistrate Kiraoli, as the bond obligated production 'whenever ordered by the court' generally (not a specific court), the magistrate exercises district-wide jurisdiction under section 12 CrPC, and forfeiture is to the Government upon default.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the appellant were permitted to raise this question in the present case without any question of fact and purely on the construction of the bond it would appear that the appellant bound himself to produce the truck whenever ordered by the court to produce the same. Therefore, there was no undertaking to produce the truck in a particular court. The undertaking was to the court of the Magistrate. The Magistrate exercises jurisdiction in the whole district under section 12 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Furthermore, the bond provided that in case of default the appellant bound himself to forfeit to the Government the amount covered by the bond sum of Rs. 20,000.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of bond terms ('the court', not specific court; liability to Government); distinguishes Bombay High Court precedent (bond specified particular court); applies s.12 CrPC for magistrate's district jurisdiction.
